contentrichtext.text: {{Taxobox | name = Yellow-billed Pintail | status = LC | status_system = IUCN3.1 | status_ref =<ref>{{IUCN|IUCN_Year=2009.2|ID=141528|title=Anas georgica|author=BirdLife International|year=2009}}</ref> | image = Anas georgica -Curitiba Zoo, Parana, Brazil-8a.jpg | image_width = 250px | image_caption = A Chilean Pintail at Curitiba Zoo, Parana, Brazil | regnum = [[Animalia]] | phylum = [[Chordate|Chordata]] | classis = [[bird|Aves]] | ordo = [[Anseriformes]] | familia = [[Anatidae]] | subfamilia = [[Anatinae]] | genus = ''[[Anas]]'' | species = '''''A. georgica''''' | binomial = ''Anas georgica'' | binomial_authority = [[Johann Friedrich Gmelin|Gmelin]], 1789 | synonyms = *''Dafila georgica'' | subdivision_ranks = [[Subspecies]] | subdivision = * ''A. g. georgica'' <small>Gmelin, 1789</small><br><small>([[South Georgia Pintail]])</small> * ''A. g. spinicauda'' <small>Vieillot, 1816</small><br><small>([[Chilean Pintail]])</small> * ''A. g. niceforoi'' <small>Wetmore & Borrero, 1946</small><br><small>([[Niceforo's Pintail]] - '''[[extinct]]''')</small> }} The '''Yellow-billed Pintail''' ('''''Anas georgica''''') is a [[South America]]n [[dabbling duck]] of the genus ''Anas'' with three described subspecies. ==Description== The Yellow-billed Pintail has a brown head and neck. The bill is yellow with a black tip and a black stripe down the middle. The tail is brownish and pointed. The upper wing is grayish-brown, and the secondaries are blackish-green. The rest of the body is buffish brown with varying size black spots. The species is sometimes confused with [[Yellow-billed Teal]], but can be differentiated by the yellow stripes on its bill, its larger size and its tendency not to form large groups. ==Distribution and habitat== [[File:Anas georgica -Puerto Natales, Patagonia, Chile-8 (1).jpg|left|thumb|At [[Puerto Natales]], Patagonia, Chile]] The range includes much of South America, the [[Falkland Islands]] and [[South Georgia]]. The nominate and smallest subspecies, the [[South Georgia Pintail]] ''A. g. georgica'', is thought to number between 1000 and 1500 pairs, and is found only in South Georgia. The [[Chilean Pintail|Chilean, or Brown, Pintail]] ''A. g. spinicauda'' is widespread on the South American mainland from extreme southern Colombia southwards, as well as in the [[Falkland Islands]], and numbers well over 110,000. [[Niceforo's Pintail]] ''A. g. niceforoi'', formerly found in central Colombia, is believed to be extinct, having been last recorded in 1952 (and described only in 1946). Their habitat ranges from high elevation lakes and marshes to low elevation lakes and rivers and coasts in open country.<ref name=WI>{{cite web |url=http://wildlife1.wildlifeinformation.org/S/0AvAnserif/anatidae/1acravan_anas/anas_georgica/anas_georgica.html#Intraspecific |title=''Anas georgica'' - Yellow-billed Pintail |accessdate=2010-07-14 |work=Debra Bourne|publisher=Wildlife Information |date= }}</ref> ==Breeding== Nests are formed on the ground and lined with grass and down. They hide their nests in vegetation close to water. They lay 4 to 10 eggs in a clutch. ==Gallery== <gallery widths="200px" heights="150px" > Image:Yellow-billed Pintail RWD2.jpg </gallery> == References == {{reflist}} == External links == {{Commons category|Anas georgica}} [[Category:Anas]] [[Category:Ducks]] [[Category:Birds of South America]]
